awd_titl_txt: Myocardial Remodeling: Role of Microstructural Cell-ECM Mechanical Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the main reasons for heart failure due to hypertension is that the structure of the heart tissue changes with time, altering its mechanical capabilities. The heart tissue is mainly made of two "materials": cells (called myocytes) and fibers (specifically, collagen fibers). Cells and fibers "push and pull" on one another while the heart beats: this is called mechanical coupling. Because hypertension alters the composition of the tissue -- cells become bigger and fibers grow in number -- it is intuitive to think that it will also have an impact on how cells and fibers interact. The goal of this project is to use advanced modeling and computations and careful experiments to understand how hypertension affects the mechanical coupling and how this change in coupling contributes to cardiac dysfunction. This study will have impact in the fields of regenerative medicine and tissue engineering, specifically in the case of new emerging heart failure treatments. Finally, this project will also serve as a platform to launch an innovative outreach program ("I heart Biomechanics") to educate and enhance public awareness of biomechanics research.  

In this project, it is hypothesized that the mechanical coupling between cells and collagen fiber network not only changes during pathological remodeling in the heart of hypertensive rats, but also is one of the significant forces driving remodeling. The overarching goal of this project is to elucidate how mechanical coupling between cells and extracellular matrix (1) drives microstructural changes in healthy and diseased hearts, (2) affects mechanical properties of the left ventricle at various stages of the remodeling, and (3) contributes to the pathological changes of the heart tissue. The approach consists of new constitutive formulations, finite element modeling, and experiments on intact tissues as well as tissues with isolated components under both active and passive conditions. In the process, a methodology will also be developed to quantify and incorporate the collagen-cells mechanical coupling into a new microstructural model for ventricular mechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to increase our understanding of how collagen fibers and myocytes interact mechanically in the left ventricle during the development of hypertension. The main outcomes of this project created new knowledge relevant to how residual stress and strain distribution within the isolated constituents of the left ventricle are affected by hypertension in a sex-dependent manner. The outcomes of this research have profound implications for emerging heart failure treatments, regenerative medicine, and pharmaceutical interventions targeting cardiac fibrosis.

Key Achievements:

1. Identification of Hypertension-Associated Changes:

For the first time, we reported changes in residual stress/strain distribution in the isolated constituents of the left ventricle, specifically linked to hypertension. These novel results are crucial, as they establish a correlation between residual stress distribution and in vivo stress distribution, which provides a foundation to increase our understanding of how biomechanical characteristics influence cellular responses and subsequently drives tissue remodeling.

2. Sex-Differences in Residual Stress Distribution:

A highly novel finding emerged as we reported, for the first time, the existence of sex differences in residual stress distribution between normotensive rats, which was not conserved in hypertensive cohorts. This result highlights the crucial need to consider sex as a significant biological variable in cardiovascular biomechanics research. The impact of this report is large as it underscores the necessity of including both sexes in future research in soft tissue biomechanics.

3. Relevance to Heart Failure Treatments:

The outcomes of this project have direct relevance to emerging heart failure treatments, particularly those involving collagen-myocyte coupling. In regenerative medicine, where collagen fiber scaffolds are recellularized with stem cells to engineer functional organs, and in pharmaceutical therapies targeting cardiac fibrosis, an increased understanding of collagen-myocyte mechanical coupling is crucial. The novel results that emerged from this project have the potential of significantly impacting treatment strategies and outcomes.

4. Methodological Advancements:

Beyond cardiovascular health, this research offers consistent protocols for advancements in testing isolated constituents, providing a methodology to investigate inter-constituent mechanical interactions. By isolating and investigating the mechanical contributions of different tissue components such as collagen and myocytes, this project opens the door to new exploration of mechanical differences between sexes.

The knowledge gained from this project lays the foundation for future research directions, potentially leading to enhanced therapies and interventions in cardiovascular health and beyond. The insights gained into collagen-myocyte mechanical coupling and residual stress distributions will inform the development and optimization of treatments, addressing critical gaps in our understanding of heart failure and related conditions.

In conclusion, this project has not only deepened our understanding of cardiovascular mechanics but has also laid the groundwork for transformative possibilities in regenerative medicine and pharmaceutical interventions. The outcomes reported herein offer a promising trajectory towards healthier hearts and a more comprehensive comprehension of mechanical intricacies in diverse tissues. The impact of this research extends far beyond the laboratory, directly benefiting society and aligning with the overarching goals of NSF.


Last Modified: 02/21/2024
Modified by: Sara Roccabianca
